===Photojournalism and documentary work=== Canadian-born [[Jessie Tarbox Beals|Jessie Tarbox]] (1870–1942) is credited with being America's earliest female photojournalist, photographing the Massachusetts state prison for the ''[[Boston Post]]'' in 1899. She was then hired by ''The Buffalo Inquirer'' and ''The Courier'' in 1902.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/coll/womphotoj/bealsessay.html "Jessie Tarbox Beals (1870–1942)]", The Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Reading Room. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Harriet Chalmers Adams]] (1875–1937) was an explorer whose expedition photographs were published in [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]. She served as a correspondent for [[Harper's Magazine]] in Europe during [[World War I]], the only female journalist permitted to visit the trenches.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/8-unsung-women-explorers-180658286.html "8 Unsung Women Explorers"], Yahoo News, 30 April 2012. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> Another war correspondent based in France during World War I was [[Helen Johns Kirtland]] (1890–1979) where she worked for ''[[Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper|Leslie's Weekly]]''.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/coll/womphotoj/kirtlandresources.html "Helen Johns Kirtland (1890–1979): Biographical Essay"], Library of Congress. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref>
[[Margaret Bourke-White]] (1906–1971) was the first foreigner to photograph Soviet industry as well as the first female war correspondent and the first woman photographer to work for [[Life (magazine)|Life]].<ref>[http://www.lkwdpl.org/wihohio/bour-mar.htm "Margaret Bourke-White"], ''Women in History''. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> During the [[Great Depression]], [[Dorothea Lange]] (1895–1965) was employed by the [[Resettlement Administration]] to photograph displaced farm families and migrant workers. Distributed free to newspapers, her images became icons of the times.<ref>[http://www.crmagazine.org/archive/SpringSummer2010/Pages/DorotheaLangeEsophagealCancer.aspx Corinna Wu, "American Eyewitness"], ''CR Magazine''. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> The novelist [[Eudora Welty]] also photographed families affected by the Great Depression, especially in rural Mississippi, producing a remarkable body of work.<ref>[http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/The-Writers-Eye.html T.A. Frail, "Eudora Welty as Photographer"], ''Smithsonian magazine'', April 2009. Retrieved 20 May 2013.</ref> In the early 1930s, [[Marvin Breckinridge Patterson]] (1905–2002) published her world travel photographs in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'', ''[[Look (American magazine)|Look]]'', ''[[Life magazine|Life]]'', ''[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]'', and ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]''.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/wcf/wcf0009.html "Women Come to the Front: Marvin Breckinridge Patterson"], Library of Congress. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Marion Carpenter]] (1920–2002) was the first female national press photographer and the first woman to cover the [[White House]].<ref>[http://www.whnpa.org/about/carpenter.htm "Remembering Marion Carpenter"], Associated Press, 25 January 2002. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Edie McKee Harper|Edie Harper]] (1922-2010) was an [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Army Corps of Engineers]] photographer during WWII, where she took photographs of different structures on the home front, such as hydro dams and cement test samples. Edie processed the film in the lab for the Corps of Engineers.<ref>Bauer, Marilyn (August 4, 2002). "Cincinnati Modernists Reunited". The Cincinnati Enquirer.</ref> Photographs from her war work became highly acclaimed and were shown in an exhibition at the Cincinnati Contemporary Art Center in 1961.<ref>"Visionary Artists at the Carnegie Arts Center :: AEQAI". aeqai.com. Retrieved 2017-03-11</ref><ref>Villarreal, Ignacio. "Discover the Art of Cincinnati's Own Charley and Edie Harper at the Cincinnati Art Museum". artdaily.com. Retrieved 2017-03-11.</ref>
[[Mary Ellen Mark]] (March 20, 1940 – May 25, 2015) was an American photographer known for her [[photojournalism]] / [[documentary photography]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/27/mary-ellen-mark|title=Mary Ellen Mark obituary|last=O'Hagan|first=Sean|date=2015-05-27|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> portraiture, and advertising<ref name="nytimes-grimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/27/arts/design/mary-ellen-mark-photographer-who-documented-difficult-subjects-dies-at-75.html|title=Mary Ellen Mark, Photographer Who Documented Difficult Subjects, Dies at 75|last=Grimes|first=William|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=28 May 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref name="huffingtonpost-dobnik">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/26/mary-ellen-mark-dead_n_7446878.html|title=Beloved Documentary Photographer Mary Ellen Mark Dies At 75|last=Dobnik|first=Verena|date=26 May 2015|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=28 May 2015}}</ref> as well as filmmaker. Her specialty was documenting from marginalized communities who were "away from mainstream society and toward its more interesting, often troubled fringes"<ref name="salon">[http://www.salon.com/people/bc/2000/03/28/mark/ Long, Andrew. "Brilliant Careers: Mary Ellen Mark"], ''[[Salon.com|Salon]]'', March 28, 2000</ref> She had 18 publications produced, most notably ''Streetwise''<ref name="independent-saul">{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/mary-ellen-mark-renowned-documentary-photographer-dies-aged-75-10278354.html | date = 27 May 2015 | accessdate = 28 May 2015 | first = Heather | last = Saul | newspaper = [[The Independent]] | location = London | title = Mary Ellen Mark: Renowned documentary photographer dies aged 75}}</ref> that also became a documentary with [[Martin Bell (director)|Martin Bell]] and ''Ward 81''.<ref name="ohagan-guardian-obit">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/27/mary-ellen-mark | date = 27 May 2015 | accessdate = 27 May 2015 | first = Sean | last = O'Hagan | authorlink = Sean O'Hagan (journalist) | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | title = Mary Ellen Mark obituary}}</ref>[http://www.maryellenmark.com/text/magazines/american%20photographer/911T-000-001.html]<ref name="time-obituary-laurent">{{cite news | url = http://time.com/3896572/mary-ellen-mark-dies-at-75/ | date = May 26, 2015 | accessdate = May 26, 2015 | first = Olivier | last = Laurent | magazine = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | title = In Memoriam: Mary Ellen Mark (1940–2015)}}</ref> For ''Ward 81'' (1979), she lived for six weeks with the patients in the women’s security ward of [[Oregon State Hospital]]. Her photos can be found in major magazines in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[New York Times]]'', and ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''. In 1977 to 1998, she became a member of [[Magnum Photos]]. Besides receiving [[Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award]]s, three fellowships from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], the 2014 Lifetime Achievement in Photography Award from the [[George Eastman House]] and the Outstanding Contribution Photography Award from the [[World Photography Organisation]], she received many other awards of recognition.
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Lange-MigrantMother02.jpg|[[Dorothea Lange]]: ''Migrant Mother'' (1936) File:Tarbox William Howard Taft Governor-General of the Philippines.jpg|[[Jessie Tarbox Beals]]: William Howard Taft at the St. Louis World's Fair (1904) File:Treaty of Versailles Signing, Hall of Mirrors.jpg|[[Helen Johns Kirtland]]: Signing of the Treaty of Versailles in the Hall of Mirrors (1919) File:Rio de Janeiro's waterfront, 1919.jpg|[[Harriet Chalmers Adams]]: ''Rio de Janeiro's waterfront and the Morro de Castello from the Ilha das Cobras'' (1919) File:US-Luftbild 1945 Würzburg Domstr. m b-w 4892665549.jpg|[[Margaret Bourke-White]]: Aerial photo of the inner city of the destroyed Wurzburg (1945) </gallery>
==Surrealism== A number of women used photography as a medium for expressing their interest in [[Surrealism]]. [[Claude Cahun]] (1894–1954) from France is remembered for her highly staged self-portraits which she began taking in the 1920s.<ref>Kate Salter, [http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG3363979/Claude-Cahun-The-surreal-deal.html "Claude Cahun: The surreal deal"], ''The Telegraph'', 6 January 2008. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> Croatian-born [[Dora Maar]] (1907–1997) also developed her interest in Surrealism in France, associating with [[André Breton]] and others. Her vivid portraits from the early 1930s bring out the features of the face as if drawn by an artist.<ref>[http://www.newyorkartworld.com/reviews/maar.html Donald Goddard, "Dora Maar: Photographer"], ''New York Art World''. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> The American [[Lee Miller]] (1907–1977) combined her fashion photography with Surrealism, associating with [[Pablo Picasso]] in Paris before returning to New York. She created some of the most striking nude photographs of the times.<ref>[http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/l/lee-miller/ "Lee Miller"], V&A. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
Surrealism continued to attract the interest of women photographers in the second half of the 20th century. [[Henriette Grindat]] (1923–1986) was one of the few Swiss women to develop an interest in artistic photography, associating with André Breton and later collaborating with [[Albert Camus]], with whom she published images of the [[Sorgue|River Sorgue]] in the south of France.<ref>[http://lejournaldelaphotographie.com/entries/4942/henriette-grindat-ou-l-anticonformisme "Henriette Grindat or the nonconformist"], ''Journal de la Photographie''. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> From the late 1940s, The Czech [[Emila Medková]] (1928–1985) began producing surrealistic works in 1947, above all remarkable documentary images of the urban environment in the oppressive post-war years.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/research/publications/tate-papers/emila-medkova-magic-despair Krzysztof Fijałkowski, "Emila Medková: The Magic of Despair"], Tate, 1 October 2005. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> Though not strictly a Surrealist, the notable Mexican photographer [[Lola Álvarez Bravo]] (1907–1993) displayed elements of Surrealism throughout her career, especially in her portraits of [[Frida Kahlo]] and [[María Izquierdo (artist)|María Izquierdo]].<ref>[http://www.manchestergalleries.org/angelsofanarchy/resources/artists "Artist Biographies: Lola Alvarez Bravo"], Manchester Galleries. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> During her short life [[Francesca Woodman]] (1958–1981), influenced by André Breton and [[Man Ray]], explored the relationship between the body and its surroundings often appearing partly hidden in her black-and-white prints.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/francesca-woodman-10512 "Francesca Woodman 1958–1981"], Tate. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
==Evolving American participation== Peter E. Palmquist who researched the history of women photographers in California and the American West from 1850 to 1950 found that in the 19th century some 10% of all photographers in the area were women while by 1910 the figure was up to about 20%. In the early days, most women working commercially were married to a photographer. Indeed, up to 1890, any woman working on her own was considered to be daring. As the process became easier to handle, more amateurs emerged, many participating in photographic organizations.<ref>[http://www.cla.purdue.edu/WAAW/palmquist/Essays.htm#e21 Peter E. Palmquist, "Preface"], ''Women in Photography Archive''. Retrieved 14 May 2013.</ref>
In the 20th century, according to scholars, it was hard for women to become successful photographers.<ref name="auto">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/36589970|title=Silent witnesses : representations of working-class women in the United States|last=1969-|first=Ellis, Jacqueline,|date=1998|publisher=Bowling Green State University Popular Press|isbn=9780879727444|location=Bowling Green, OH|oclc=36589970}}</ref>
===Portraits=== [[Marian Hooper Adams]] (1843–1885) was one of America's earliest [[portrait photography|portrait photographers]] taking portraits of family, friends and politicians from 1883 and doing all the developing herself.<ref>[http://www.masshist.org/findingaids/doc.cfm?fa=fap007 "Marian Hooper Adams Photographs"], Massachusetts Historical Society. Retrieved 14 May 2013.</ref> [[Sarah Choate Sears]] (1858–1935) gained international attention as an amateur photographer after she began producing fine portraits and flower studies. She soon became a member of London's [[The Linked Ring|Linked Ring]] and New York's [[Photo-Secession]].<ref>[http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artMakerDetails?maker=1706 "Sarah Choate Sears"], The J. Paul Getty Museum. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Elizabeth Buehrmann]] from Chicago (c. 1886–1963) specialized in taking portraits of leading businessmen and prominent society women in their own homes at the beginning of the 20th century, becoming a member of the famous Paris Photo-Club in 1907.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Helen|last=Goodman|date=Winter 1995|title=Elizabeth Buehrmann, American Pictorialist|journal=History of Photography|volume=19|issue=4|pages=338–341|doi=10.1080/03087298.1995.10443589}}</ref> [[Caroline Gurrey]] (1875–1927) is remembered for her series on mixed-race children taken in Hawaii from 1904. Many were exhibited at the [[Alaska–Yukon–Pacific Exposition]] in Seattle.<ref>[http://www.mixedracestudies.org/wordpress/?tag=caroline-haskins-gurrey Heather Waldroup, "Ethnographic Pictorialism: Caroline Gurrey’s Hawaiian Types at the Alaska–Yukon–Pacific Exposition"], Mixed Race Studies. Retrieved 14 May 2013.</ref> [[Doris Ulmann]] (1884–1934) started out as an amateur pictorialist photographer but became a professional in 1918. In addition to portraits of promintent intellectuals, she documented the mountain peoples of the south, especially the [[Appalachia]]ns.<ref>[http://library.uoregon.edu/speccoll/photo/ulmann/index.html "Doris Ulmann Collection"], University of Oregon Libraries. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref>
In the 1930s, [[Consuelo Kanaga]] (1894–1978) photographed many well-known artists and writers becoming one of the few photographers to produce artistic portraits. Her photograph of a slender black women and her children was included in [[Edward Steichen]]'s ''[[The Family of Man|Family of Man]]'' exhibition in 1955.<ref>{{cite book|author=Barbara Head Millstein and Susan Lowe|title=Consuelo Kanaga, An American Photographer|publisher=Seattle: University of Washington Press|year=1992|pages=21–40}}</ref> [[Ruth Harriet Louise]] (1903–1940) was first woman photographer active in Hollywood where she ran [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]'s portrait studio from 1925 to 1930 photographing numerous stars including as [[Greta Garbo]] and [[Joan Crawford]].<ref>Dance, R.; B. Robertson, ''Ruth Harriet Louise and Hollywood Glamour Photography'', University of California Press 2002; {{ISBN|0-520-23347-6}}.</ref>

== African-American women in photography ==
=== History ===
Photographs are pictures ''about'' and ''of'' things (Birt). As society has evolved, African-American photographers have been critical in the preservation of authentic portrayals of images ''about ''and ''of ''black culture. The participation of African-American women in photography began to receive widespread acknowledgment in the mid-20th century and with growing recognition came a shift in focus on social, economic, and political conditions. Some of the most prominent female African-American photographers include [[Carrie Mae Weems]], [[Lorna Simpson]], and [[Coreen Simpson]].
==== Carrie Mae Weems ==== Born in [[Portland, Oregon]], [[Carrie Mae Weems]] started her career in 1973 when she received her first camera. Her initial interest in the arts started in 1965, when she met lifelong friend Tom Vinters and began participating in street theater and dance. Though noted as an accomplished photographer, Weems' work spans text, fabric, audio, digital images, installation, and video. "…from the very beginning I've been interested in the idea of power and the consequences of power; relationships are made and articulated through power."<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Carrie Mae Weems|last = Bey|first = Dawoud|date = Summer 2009|journal = BOMB|doi = |pmid = |jstor=40428266|pages=60–67}}</ref> When exploring the idea of power, Weems oftentimes uses herself as the subject of her work, not for her own admiration, but "as a vehicle for approaching the question of power…"<ref name=":0" />
Through different mediums, Weems has made it her mission to explore the family relationships, gender roles, the histories of racism, sexism, class and different types of political systems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://carriemaeweems.net/bio.html|title= Carrie Mae Weems|date= |accessdate=12 April 2015 |website = carriemaeweems|publisher = Lisa Goodlin Design|last = Weems|first = Carrie Mae}}</ref> She was introduced to [[Dawoud Bey]] in 1976 and developed a long lasting friendship and professional relationship with the photographer. While on a work trip to Europe, Bey interviewed Weems in BOMB, a magazine focused on artists in conversation. [[File:LornaSimpsonApr09 cropped.jpg|right|150px|thumb|Lorna Simpson]]
==== Lorna Simpson ==== [[Lorna Simpson]] began her career in fashion photography, taking pictures of people whose style she admired. Simpson was able to develop her skills and became a photojournalist who captured images in politics, culture, music, and sports.
Receiving her education in photography at the [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York and the [[University of California, San Diego]], Lorna Simpson was considered a pioneer of conceptual photography well before the peak of her career. Through her work, Simpson aims to challenge the traditional views of gender, identity, culture, history, and memory as viewed by society. Her combination of large-scale photography with meaningful text work together to provide strong visual implications.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.lsimpsonstudio.com/#mi=11&pt=0&pi=6&p=-1&a=-1&at=0|title = Lorna Simpson|accessdate =15 April 2015|website = Lorna Simpson Studio|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Her work can be found in museums across the country at the [[Museum of Modern Art, New York|Museum of Modern Art]] (NY), the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago|Museum of Contemporary Art]] (Chicago, IL), and the [[Walker Art Center]] (Minneapolis), and many others around the world.
==== Coreen Simpson ==== Making her mark as a photojournalist, [[Coreen Simpson]] started her career as a published writer. Her interest in documenting experiences in writing grew into a love for the visual arts when she contacted Essence magazine about an article she wanted to write about a business trip to the Middle East. Although the article was never published, her interest in photojournalism was heightened.
In his article "Coreen Simpson: An Interpretation", Rodger Birt describes looking at a photograph as being "let in on the workings of another human consciousness" allowing for the simultaneous opportunity to receive an authentic depiction of the physical world.<ref name="Birt">{{cite journal|last1=Birt|first1=Rodger|title=Coreen Simpson: An Interpretation|journal=Black American Literature Forum|date=1987|volume=21|issue=3|pages=289–304|jstor=2904032|doi=10.2307/2904032}}</ref> Through her work, Simpson has created visual narratives that aesthetically tell the stories of diverse groups of people. Not only is she able to evoke emotional responses through her storytelling, but through design, [[chiaroscuro]], and color as well.
Simpson's friend, Walter Johnson, became one of her biggest mentors and guide as she expanded her knowledge in photography. She also studied Frank Stewart's process and developed a strong capacity for the history of photography. One of her biggest struggles was to differentiate her visual style from those of her inspiration.
The four greatest influences of Simpson's work include [[Diane Arbus]], [[Adolph de Meyer|Baron Adolph DeMeyer]], [[Joel Peter Witkin]], and [[Weegee]]. Whether conceptually, methodically, or creatively, each of these photographers have contributed to her approach in different ways.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|jstor = 2904032|title = Coreen Simpson: An Interpretation|last = Birt|first = Rodger|date = Autumn 1997|journal = Black American Literature Forum|doi = |pmid = }}</ref>
The combination of her admiration for Arbus's uniqueness, Weegee's hunt, DeMeyer's study of the compostition, and Witkin's manipulation of the print work together in encompassing the personality of Coreen Simpson's work.<ref name=":1" />
'''Elizabeth "Tex" Williams'''
[[Elizabeth Williams (photographer)|Elizabeth "Tex" Williams]] was a world war 2 military photographer. She was in the last year of war.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/29733207|title=Viewfinders : black women photographers|last=1951-|first=Moutoussamy-Ashe, Jeanne,|date=1993|publisher=Writers & Readers Pub|isbn=0863161588|location=New York|oclc=29733207}}</ref> She was one of the first women to have a photography career beyond "camera girl".<ref name="auto"/>
==UK women's agency== In the [[United Kingdom]] the women's photographic agency [[Format (photographic agency)|Format]] was set up in 1983, from an idea conceived by Maggie Murray and [[Val Wilmer]].<ref>[http://sounds.bl.uk/Arts-literature-and-performance/Art-photography-and-architecture/021M-C0459X0046XX-1200V0 "Art, photography & architecture: Wilmer, Val (12 of 13). Oral History of British Photography"], [[British Library]], Sounds.</ref><ref>Amanda Hopkinson, [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/sep/21/raissa-page-obituary "Raissa Page obituary"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 September 2011.</ref> Operating for two decades, until 2003, Format represented women photographers including Jackie Chapman, [[Anita Corbin]], [[Melanie Friend]], Sheila Gray, Paula Glassman, Judy Harrison, Pam Isherwood, [[Roshini Kempadoo]], Jenny Mathews, Joanne O'Brien, Raissa Page, Brenda Prince, Ulrike Preuss, Mirium Reik, Karen Robinson, Paula Solloway, Mo Wilson and Lisa Woollett.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cpt.qedstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/format-photographers.pdf|title="Format Photographers Agency 1983–2003".|author=|date=|website=qedstudio.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.photofusion.org/exhibitions/ultimate-format/ "Ultimate Format | Format Women Photographers 1983 – 2003"], Photofusion.</ref>
==Contemporary== Contemporary women photographers continue to break ground in the field of photography. [[Annie Leibovitz]] captures arresting, usually posed, images of the famous and the unknown, publishing photographs for the covers of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', ''Vogue'', and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', representing a broad survey of American popular culture.<ref>[http://www.infoplease.com/encyclopedia/people/leibovitz-annie.html "Annie Leibovitz"], Infoplease. Retrieved 14 December 2015.</ref>
[[Cindy Sherman]]'s work turns still photography into performance art to explore traditional and pop-cultural myths of femininity. Her work implicitly examines issues of identity and stereotype, representation and reality, the function of mass media, and the nature of portraiture.<ref>[http://www.infoplease.com/encyclopedia/people/sherman-cindy.html "Cindy Sherman"], Infoplease. Retrieved 14 December 2015.</ref>
The contemporary works of women photographers is numerous. Women only photography exhibits are controversial yet essential to highlight the imbalance of male domination in the field throughout the history of photography, and are becoming increasingly more common.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2018-05-11|title=Female Artists Are (Finally) Getting Their Turn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/03/arts/design/the-resurgence-of-women-only-art-shows.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=29 March 2016|issn=0362-4331|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2018-05-11|title=‘Women in Photography’ explores diverse possibilities of familiar medium|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/visual-arts/women-in-photography-explores-diverse-possibilities-of-familiar-medium/|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=29 August 2017}}</ref>
==Awards== In 1903, [[Emma Barton (photographer)|Emma Barton]] (1872–1938) was the first woman to be awarded the [[Royal Photographic Society]] medal. It was for a [[carbon print]] entitled ''The Awakening''.<ref>[http://www.nationalmediamuseum.org.uk/Collection/Photography/RoyalPhotographicSociety/CollectionItem.aspx?id=2003-5001/2/20914 "The Awakening"], Royal Photographic Society. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
The [[Pulitzer Prize for Photography]] has been awarded to outstanding work in press photography since 1942. The first woman to receive the award was [[Virginia Schau]] (1915–1989), an amateur who photographed two men being rescued from a tractor trailer cab as it dangled from a bridge in [[Redding, California]].<ref>Frank Van Riper, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/photo/galleries/essays/001229.htm "Pulitzer Pictures: Capturing the Moment"], Washingtonpost.com. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
In 2000, Marcia Reed (born 1948), the first female still photographer to join the [[International Cinematographers Guild]] also became the first women to win the [[Society of Operating Cameramen]] Lifetime Achievement Award for Still Photography in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://socawards.com/past-soc-lifetime-achievement-awards/|title=PAST SOC LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARDS|author=|date=6 December 2014|website=socawards.com}}</ref>
